item.title: Most Recurring Word on each Country's Wikipedia Page
item.description: A friend recently offered me a fun book: *Brilliant maps. An atlas for curious minds*. One of the maps, called *Most recurring word on each country‚Äôs English Wikipedia page*, particularly caught my attention. This world map shows the most frequent word of each country‚Äôs English Wikipedia page.

item.title: Introducing my new R package {BFS}
item.description: The [Swiss Federal Statistical Office](https://www.bfs.admin.ch/bfs/en/home.html), or BFS from ‚ÄúBundesamt f√ºr Statistik‚Äù in German, provides a rich public database. As Swiss citizen and R enthousiast, I wanted to easily access its datasets directly from R. So I created the [BFS package](https://felixluginbuhl.com/BFS/).

item.title: The Evolution of Regional Inequalities Around the World
item.description: Last month *Nature* published [a paper](https://www.nature.com/articles/sdata201938) introducing new data on regional human development across the globe. The Subnational Human Development Index (SHDI) Database contains data on 1625 regions of 161 countries, covering all regions and development levels of the world. It provides their Human Development Index with related indicators. I couldn't resist to have a look at this new database and try some exploratory analysis.

item.title: Is There Gender Equality in the Pok√©mon Universe?
item.description: With more than 13 millions of subscribers, Reddit's *[Data Is Beautiful](https://www.reddit.com/r/dataisbeautiful/comments/9cuzs3/battle_dataviz_battle_for_the_month_of_september/)* is one of the main online forum on data visualization. Last week I came accross the funny dataset of the current DataViz monthly challenge: [Information on All 802 Pokemon](https://www.kaggle.com/rounakbanik/pokemon). Having a quick look at the data, I discovered with surprize a `percentage_male` variable. I wasn‚Äôt aware that Pok√©mon have genders. So I decided to dig further into this gender dimension of the Pok√©mon universe.

item.title: Slides of my Talk at the R Users Meetup Geneva
item.description: This July I had the chance to speak at the [R Users Meetup Geneva](https://www.meetup.com/fr-FR/Geneve-R-User-Group/events/jmglvpyxjblc/). I shared the learnings of my year-long exploration of the tidyverse through blogging. It was such a pleasure to meet and discuss with other R users as passionnate as I am!

item.title: Can you Guess a Cuisine from its Ingredients?
item.description: Cooking is sometimes used as a metaphor for data preparation in machine learning. In order to practice my skills in machine learning, I decided to look for a dataset related to cooking. After a quick research online, I found [this](https://www.kaggle.com/c/whats-cooking/data) Kaggle dataset. In this Kaggle competition, the game is to predict the category of a dish‚Äôs cuisine given a list of its ingredients.

item.title: Reproducing The Economist Most Popular Map of 2017
item.description: I am a big fan of The Economist charts, in particular the ones published in the Graphic details blog. According to their Christmas countdown, The Economist most popular map of 2017 were this one (see below). In this article, we will reproduce it with `ggplot2`, `sf` and `leaflet`.

item.title: Predicting the Number of Swiss Phone Calls per Hour
item.description: I recently heard that one of the major Swiss telecommunications provider, Swisscom AG, decided to share data on a [Open Data Portal](https://opendata.swisscom.com/pages/home/?flg=en). As Swiss citizen, I was curious to see if I could put my hand on interesting datasets.

item.title: My Package {polyglot} Is Now on CRAN
item.description: A few months ago, I wrote my first package called {learner}. I finally took the time to put it on CRAN. Following the advice of a CRAN team member, I changed its name. I had to agree: it sounded like a machine learning package. So now the {learner} package is dead, long life to {[polyglot](https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=polyglot)}!

item.title: Do the Rich Countries Always Win?
item.description: Like most of us, I watched the Olympics Winter Games. But after seeing the [medal table](https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/game-time/results/OWG2018/en/general/medal-standings.htm), I had the impression that the richer a country was, the more medals he got. But was it really the case? And if yes, to what extent?

item.title: Which Marvel Characters and Movies are the Most Central?
item.description: To begin this year, I was looking for a quick project related to social network visualization. As R analyses on [Game of Thrones](https://shiring.github.io/networks/2017/05/15/got_final), [Star Wars](https://rpubs.com/ogimenez/200849) or [The Lord of The Rings](http://mildlyscientific.schochastics.net/2016/08/10/the-lord-of-the-rings-the-three-networks/) have already been done, I decided to visualize the superhero network of the nowadays very popular Marvel movies saga. In this blog post, we will find out which characters and movies are the most central in the Marvel cinematic universe.

item.title: The Lack of Female Protagonists in Children‚Äôs Movies
item.description: Some time ago, I read a very interesting [post](http://giorasimchoni.com/2017/09/24/2017-09-24-where-my-girls-at/) from Giora Simchoni who used machine learning to estimate how many children's books have a central female character. Based on [this](https://www.goodreads.com/list/show/226.Favorite_books_from_my_childhood) Goodread list, he showed that for every book with a central female character, there are between 1.1 and 1.3 books written with a male protagonist. I couldn't help thinking that his analysis should be replicated on children's movies.

item.title: Introducing My Second R Package, {bfsdata}
item.description: The {bfsdata} package makes the data from the Swiss Federal Statistical Office (or BFS for "Bundesamt f√ºr Statistik") easily accessible to R users. It lets you search, download and read BFS datasets directly from the R console.

item.title: Who's The Most Popular Tennis Player on Twitter?
item.description: In the world of men's tennis, only four players, known as the "[Big Four](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_Four_(tennis))", have dominated the main tournaments since 2004. You probably know their names: Roger Federer, Rafael Nadal, Novak Djokovic and Andy Murray. As they regularly make the headlines all over the world, I wanted to know more about their popularity on Twitter with the R packages {rtweet} and {tidytext}.

item.title: James Bond Tourism
item.description: James Bond must be the most well-travelled man in the history of movies. As it is summer time, let's have a look at the 007 travel locations in the 24 films of the spy franchise with the R packages {maps}, {ggplot2} and {ggmap}.

item.title: Orwell‚Äôs 1984, An (Un)Sentimental Analysis
item.description: Dystopian books are trendy. After Donald Trump's election, George Orwell novel 1984 hit the No. 1 spot in Amazon‚Äôs book sales chart. Also because I love this book, let's make a text analysis using the R package {tidytext}.
